Authors:
Anna V. Williams, Laura M. Boykin, Paul G. Nevill, Ian
Small
Title:
Does sequencing the complete plastid genome improve species
discrimination: a test in Acacia
Keywords:
species discrimination, plastid sequencing, sliding window
analysis, Acacia
Abstract:
The standard plant DNA barcoding loci, matK and rbcL, are
often found to be limited in their capacity to discriminate between
species. Advances in sequencing technology mean that we can now produce
whole chloroplast genome sequences relatively easily, and here we
examine the potential of whole chloroplast genome for species
discrimination in Acacia. We firstly examine the traditional barcoding
loci and the nuclear ITS regions for their ability to uniquely
discriminate among previously identified specimens. Then we use a
sliding window analysis to identify potential barcoding loci within the
chloroplast genome, and compare the ability of these loci to resolve
supported monophyletic species with that of the whole chloroplast
genome. Our results suggest that using traditional barcoding loci
resulted in only 57% of specimens belonging to a species-specific
monophyletic clade, while our sliding window analysis revealed that 65%
of specimens could be successfully placed in a species-specific
monophyletic clade by using larger subsections of the chloroplast
genome. However, using the whole chloroplast genome for species
discrimination gave the highest number of species-specific monophyletic
clades. Given the resolution with high statistical support using the
whole chloroplast genome and the other advantages this method provides,
we conclude that, despite representing a greater technical challenge,
the whole chloroplast genome provides a superior means to species
discrimination to traditional plant DNA barcoding loci.
